text: John Michael Bishop (born February 22, 1936) is an American immunologist and microbiologist. He shared the 1989 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with Harold Varmus and was co-winner of 1984 Alfred P. Sloan Prize.NCI visuals online: image details. Visualsonline.cancer.gov. Retrieved on 2013-11-24. He currently serves as an active faculty member at the University of California, San Francisco.Nobel Prize press release Bishop is best known for his Nobel- winning work on retroviral oncogenes. Working with Varmus in the 1980s, he discovered the first human oncogene, c-Src. Their findings showed how malignant tumors are formed from changes to the normal genes of a cell. These changes can be produced by viruses, by radiation, or by exposure to some chemicals. He was elected a foreign member of the Academia Europaea in 2002. == References == Category:American microbiologists Category:American virologists Category:1936 births Category:Living people Category:Foreign Members of the Royal Society Category:Members of Academia Europaea
